Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.

<target_code>
Here is the code of check_apply_param__thread_per_conn:
```c
static int
check_apply_param__thread_per_conn (void)
{
  if (! tool_params.thread_per_conn)
    return ! 0;

  if (tool_params.epoll)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "'Thread-per-connection' mode cannot be used together "
             "with 'epoll'.\n");
    return 0;
  }
  num_threads = 1;

  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: This function has no parameters (signature: static int check_apply_param__thread_per_conn(void)); therefore MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (a function parameter should not be modified) is not applicable. The code only reads global/tool_params members, assigns to a global num_threads, and returns values — none of these are function-parameter modifications. No pointer parameters are present, so the pointer-specific prohibition is also irrelevant. Consequently there are no fragments here that need investigation for Rule 17.8.
